data.title: Dunkin’s Coffee Isn’t Great. Here’s Why We Love It Anyway.
data.meta_description: Plus, the top five menu items to order while you’re there
data.text:
Dunkin’ — née Donuts, until the brand adopted its mononym in 2019 — is as Boston as the Red Sox, as the Marathon, as clam chowder. Most of us who grew up in Massachusetts feel a personal connection to the brand, which was founded in 1950 in Quincy and has since expanded across this country and into around 40 others.

To me, Dunkin’ tastes like that first hint of independence. Once I got my driver’s license in high school, I thought it was the absolute coolest thing to roll up to the drive-thru of the Dunkin’ Donuts on the main street of my hometown and buy a small hot French vanilla coffee with extra cream and extra sugar (I know) with the money saved from my job at Friendly’s. I listened to mixed tapes in my beat-up car while drinking coffee that tasted like melted ice cream. A quick poll of friends unearthed similar stories: Summers sipping the sadly defunct Kahlua-flavored Coolatta at the beach, long before discovering what the actual Kahlua liquor tasted like. Working closing shifts at Dunkin’ during high school and saving a box of donuts from the trash to bring it to a party (hero, that one).

Here’s the thing: Dunkin’ is not Boston’s best, well, anything. But we still hit up the spot even though we know there are better coffee and donuts around town. Go to Massachusetts-founded George Howell for fancy pour-overs and seasonal beverages, Blackbird Donuts for scratch-made confections, and Flour for perfect pastries. You can find better bagels at, well, Better Bagels. But Dunkin’ is familiar and comforting — and at this point, an inseparable stereotype tied to Boston’s identity.

What’s funny is that Dunkin’ the brand seems to be comfortable capitalizing on those stereotypes. Take a look at their viral “The DunKings” 2024 Super Bowl commercial, featuring Ben Affleck, Mat Damon, Tom Brady, Jack Harlow, Jennifer Lopez, and Fat Joe. And the other recent spots starring Affleck that rely on his affability and charm (plus exaggerated accent). Dunkin’s marketing push — the DunKings tracksuits, the New Kids on the Block pastiche “Don’t Dunk Away At My Heart” track on Spotify — seem to be in conversation with the general opinion about Boston held by outsiders, evident online and (mostly playful, usually hilarious) Saturday Night Live jokes: Boston doesn’t have good taste. Boston doesn’t know good food (we don’t even have a Michelin guide!), never mind good coffee. Cue the other complaints — the public transportation sucks! the nightlife sucks! it’s not even a “real” city! — usually from people who spent a single weekend here when they were touring colleges ten years ago.

Bostonians are a lot more than the caricature painted by the outside world — sporting a Red Sox hat, dropping our Rs, probably living in Mark Wahlberg’s old neighborhood. So why do we keep on Dunkin’? Because familiarity and comforting flavors go a long way, especially when the world is (often literally) on fire. Because the food is good. And you know what, sometimes good is great. So of course we’re going to celebrate our hometown hero. With that in mind, here’s a completely biased (but still correct) ranking of their current menu.

5. Chorizo and Egg Wrap

Something about the velvety filling makes the chorizo and egg wrap the standout of Dunkin’s sandwiches and wraps section. A red pepper lavash — its edges crisp thanks to a blast in the oven — shrouds a molten filling of egg, roasted vegetables, beans, and a slightly spicy cheese sauce. A mild smoky kick from chorizo sausage cuts through the creaminess. Think of this bite like a rice-less breakfast burrito that’s still surprisingly filling.

4. Chocolate Munchkins

It’s a proven fact that munchkins, Dunkin’s beloved donut holes, are the optimal form of donuts, owing to their size-to-flavor ratio. Chocolate is the best. Savor that dense cake-y texture, the intense, almost earthy cocoa that’s balanced both by the sweet glaze and the cake’s faintly fatty (if ominously named) Dairy Blend referenced in the company’s textbook-like ingredient guide. In the end, the chocolate munchkin’s appeal isn’t rocket science. It’s elementary — school, that is. The taste is a throwback to those grade-school holiday parties when your teacher would bring in a box of munchkins, and each chocolatey mouthful was just as sweet as a school-free week ahead.

3. French Cruller

Among a rotating roster of guest stars — like the new watermelon burst donut that answers a question nobody asked: “What if a jelly donut and a Starburst had a baby?” — is the almighty French cruller. Its ridges stand up to titular dunks in coffee, its thin lacquer of glaze lends a hint of vanilla to the fried doughy goodness. The croissant-like texture amounts to a lighter bite. You can crush three of these in one sitting, easily.

2. Blueberry Muffin

Dunkin’s entry in the “cake cosplaying as a breakfast item” category is the blueberry muffin. The faintly tart berries prevent the muffin from tasting cloying, while the slightly firmer muffin top guards a pillowy and moist center. And that dusting of crystal sugar on top? Heaven. Have it warmed up and slathered in butter, or straight-up. Either way, tear off the top and dunk it in coffee for that perfect bite.

1. Iced Coffee

Everyone has their own magic combination of dairy and sweeteners, but here’s the truth: Get it black. The flavor shots are too sweet, and the sugar-free options carry a chemical-like aftertaste. This baby fuels just as well while you brace against arctic winter wind on a T platform as a blistering day at M Street Beach. It’s a little bold, a little bitter — just like Boston.
